title: Works like a charm
text: Very easy to set up.  I like that you can take photos of your zones, create zone maps using an aerial photo of your home, etc.  It is really easy to use as hoc and in scheduled mode.  Many devices are one or the other, but this is eased or both.  This is real easy to use with Alexa too.  Will just say, “Alexa, ask Rachio to run zone 3 for 15 minutes.”  Also, I like that I can VERY simply select certain of the zones to run manually (quick run).  Literally can have that started in 10-15 seconds of zone selection time.  You can also allow professionals (your landscaper or sprinkler repair company) to access it.  This allows them to work on your sprinklers  without you having to give them your phone.  I gave this a 5 because it’s not a 4, but I think it is really a 4.5.  So far I can’t fully trust the automatic weather feature.  I am all about using water only when needed, but in our climate, if you give too little everything will die.  I noticed that it won’t run the sprinklers when the slightest bit of rain has recently occurred.  That slight bit of rain would never have been enough to get to the roots of the plants / grass.  The good news it is a easy to use that I turned off the auto weather feature, and I just manually disable the Rachio if enough rain has occurred or is obviously going to occur.

title: 3rd clock in 10 years
text: This is the third auto sprinkler clock I have tried in the past 10 years because of incredibly disappointing results and other reasons. Compared to the other two which are not relevant because of technological advances and budget this Rachio is a dream come true! Even though their information on how much water my lawn should receive is based on their opinion of a proper watering schedule based on the weather is very much different than that of the water conservatory group which I belong to.  I have watered according to local landscaping recommended schedule and my grass is the best it’s ever been in the 17 years that I’ve owned this home. The app is easy and I always know what’s going on and I can stop cycles at anytime I want, I can run manual schedules I can completely control the experience I have a super powerful Wi-Fi so it always stays connected and has not failed in three months so far. The reason I chose this brand was because if it’s in Costco, then it has usually passed a lot of consumer-protecting research and tests. I will totally back the opinion of Costco that you get your $$ worth on this system. Love my lawn!

title: Frustrating to use
text: Looks cool, seems like it will work great when you program it, and easy to program.  However so many inconsistencies and errors, if program to run in morning for short time, instead it’s running in evening for hours. Or program is set to run at 6:30 am, and it runs at 11:45 pm.  Or we have it set to run every day but Monday when it will getting mowed, and instead it says next scheduled run is two weeks from now.  Often I’m shocked to find it running at various times when it’s not meant too. Often I find that it tries to conserve so much that instead if running for 15 minutes it runs for a minute or two and new plants are dying. One zone we can’t get to run, we have had a sprinkler company come out and verify, it’s getting power and water and it’s set up and programmed right, and was working on our previous system just before switched over. It is either so convoluted and too smart for its own good, with all the skips and conservations, or even when you program it to not be, it’s doesn’t run when it should.  Takes way too much time to continually manage and override after you get it all set up and programmed, setting it up was the easy straight forward part. We have two computer science engineers at our house and neither of them like it. I do not recommend, needs major software improvements.

title: Great app and device
text: My experience with the app and Rachio 3 has been pretty much flawless. A few glitches but nothing a restart of the app didn’t resolve. I think some issues people are having is internet connectivity. If you have mediocre WiFi in your home it’s probably pretty bad in your garage if the Rachio is located there. I have a access point in my garage and the Rachio shows strong connectivity in the client list. Maybe that’s why it always works. I would totally give it 5 stars if it had a RJ45 jack on the back to possibly run it PoE (power over ethernet) over a CAT 6. This would give it rock solid connectivity and may resolve a lot of people’s issues. Sometimes when I pull my truck in the garage a certain way it will reduce the signal to 60% (metal barrier). With a hard wired connection none of these changes in everyday life would effect the connectivity and cause people to post un researched problems and immediately blame the device. Oh, and on a previous post on how the Rachio got his WiFi password. This is a HomeKit device, that’s why you bought it right? You said you had a iPhone so you are prob a iOS and AppleTV guy. HomeKit passed on the credentials and set up protocols. You can disable this.

title: Friendly App
text: This sprinkler controller is this easiest sprinkler controller I’ve ever used in the 40 years that I’ve used them. Easy to set up, easy to understand, and educational to boot! I have 2 homes and use them in both homes now. The only down side, is when your WiFi is out, so is the controller. An improvement might be to have dial up phone control as back up. This is only relevant to those with more than one home 100’s or 1000’s of miles apart! The device is extremely well made, intuitive, and durable. That’s hard to find these days. I like the flexibility of having an eight station unit in my smaller home, but a 16 station on my acreage. Both work the same and don’t take professionals to install or maintain. One can’t say that about most electronic devices!

title: App getting better but room for improvement
text: Horrendous terms of use that must be agreed to.  Convenient but unsettling how the app somehow got my WiFi password from my iphone and passed it to the Rachio hardware automatically.  I wish the app showed when my Rain sensor was wet.  I wish I could change the type of a schedule without deleting it and creating a new one.  I wish the app didn't hang when I was creating a new schedule, but it works most of the time.  App schedule display also had several inconsistencies (e.g., saying it WILL and WON'T water tomorrow on the same home screen, and Zones screen mismatch with home screen regarding next watering date).  Flex Daily schedule said it's going to water but then it skipped watering for no apparent reason when lawn was dry.  To prevent the grass dying I ran a manual schedule but the Flex Daily schedule now says it's going to water regardless that the grass is now saturated.  Home screen optionally shows monthly water usage which is useful.  The Rachio unit itself only works if their cloud service is up, so it may become a brick if Rachio's server or internet is down (can only run 3 minute manual cycles on the unit itself).  Customer service did get back to me (submitted requests through app).

title: Grass is brown, plantings dying, no Rachio response
text: System is so “smart” that it deprives you of control and easy adjustment. If you aren’t a farmer, the advanced settings on the app require an advanced understanding of soil composition / water retention that is not explained and is utterly impossible to understand.  Meantime, it is watering lightly (<30m/zone, every 4-5 days), contrary to everything my local cooperative extension has taught me about deep watering to have grass roots grow deep ... and this in mid-August on eastern Long Island. Guess what?  Grass is brown, plantings, dying for weeks, are now dead. I’ve implored Rachio for assistance, got a robo-reply saying I’d hear from them in 3-5 days.  Now more than a week later: Nothing. Now I’m just using a hose-end sprinkler (love it!) and setting the irrigation to go on manually every day or two for at least an hour/zone.  Hoping at least that I get my lawn back through artificial resuscitation. The hydrangeas and Rosa rugosa look like lost causes. Hey, thanks Rachio. (And Rachio, don’t send me to your freaking website to spend half a day trying to find solutions in your community. Either give me a manual with detailed instructions, or give me a freakin human being to walk me thru set-up. Otherwise, just send me back my old irrigation controller!!!)

title: Good App
text:
Hooking up the unit was easy enough and programming was easy as well. Love the smart features and notification.  This system runs like a charm.

I would like to see a couple enhancements. On iOS the Unit sends you notifications like on saturation of soil. However, when you go into the App you can’t see that same information. You can only see that it skipped. It would be nice to see those notifications in history on the app to understand why it skipped.  Also on the saturation skip it would be nice to have a choice to reduce water verses skipping all together.  I live in a very dry place and the ground doesn’t stay saturated for long.  My only choices are on or off.  Having a “reduce” option  would be great.

The Alexa integration needs some work (recognize more commands) but it’s pretty cool to be able to kick off the watering cycles.  I have had no issues with this unit and happy that smart tech is here for controlling watering.  You don’t have to be an electrician to hook this up and programming is pretty intuitive.  Highly recommend this product.

title: Wish I’d gotten this sooner. Great app but could use improvements
text:
I got this device to handle 11 zones of sprinklers. It’s goes above and beyond anything a rain sensor can do. Rain sensors only control sprinklers while raining. This gem gets weather, both current and future , and adjusts the smart schedule based on your lawn and gardens watering needs. I’m using so much less water. 
  My only pet peeve is when setting up the needs of the zones for smart watering. It basically gives you two options: lawn & garden, and within those two categories you set soil types and shade or sun   That’s fine. It’s very helpful. However, it should also include specialty beds for specific watering needs, such as vegetable beds. To compensate for that lack, I use programmed settings to water, or manually turn on “quick watering “ to supplement. Not a huge deal. I just think the developer can go a little further with the app. Still love this thing. And the garage wall mount panel was a snap to install too. ❤️

title: One flaw in otherwise impressive app
text:
Their “flex daily” schedule is their smartest and most dynamic scheduling option, but it was one glaring flaw.  If you tell it to be done by sunrise (the default/recommended choice), when it determines what time to START watering, so that it will be done by sunrise, it completely neglects to check the schedule it intelligently creates, and instead assumes all zones will be watering for their maximum normal duration.  For somebody like me with 10 zones, that means even though it’s only planning on watering for 4 hours, it decides it needs to start watering at 8pm.
Irrigation 101 dictates you should not start watering early in the evening, because by letting the soil and plant surface sit damp and dark all night unnecessarily, you’re going to promote disease.
This is clearly a bug in rachio’s algorithm... hopefully one they fix soon, as I already struggle with preventing brown spot in my zoysia and that was before I replaced my old school controller with this “smart” one.
Otherwise, even though I just set my system up yesterday, I’m very impressed by the controller, app and potential!

title: Controller works acceptably; app has major issues
text: The app has an annoying habit of going to a completely blank screen (on iPad Pro using iOS 12.4) at least once a day whenever I switch from a screen (for example, changing a watering duration in a given zone) back to another screen (like ‘home’). There is only a white screen with a smallblack line across the bottom center of the screen. Nothing works to get the app to respond except to delete the app and load it anew from the App Store, which gets old very quickly. Additionally, its ability to postpone scheduled waterings based on upcoming weather forecasts of rain is too dependent (100%) on a weather service, which historically is nowhere near that perfect; while it is relatively easy to override such a “rain skip” of a scheduled watering by clicking on a “run” button, that has become the antithesis of automated watering for me in five months of usage in the DFW Metroplex. It is actually proving to be easier and more efficient to turn OFF all of the apps vaunted watering aids and do a manual shut-off when experience shows heavy rain, saturated ground or high winds

title: Dissatisfied w/ current release
text: Rachio removed the feature to water all zones on the fly! I used to be able to select all zones and immediately run them consecutively based on a time allotment. Also, I don’t understand why it keeps pushing this new product Thrive on me. Thrive shows up on my home page and even has its own tab. I’m not sure but it looks like a grass or fertilizer product and I’m a xeriscape native garden, like most smart people are converting too; esp., if you’re in SoCal. I’m also an app designer, this UI isn’t as great as it used to be. I’d prefer more infographs on the home relevant to my garden water usage and local weather forecast, not ads and Thrive info. I don’t even know if my plants have been watered unless I go out there and physically check because it’s a few steps to find history on the app. I’ve got thousands of dollars of rare plants I’ve grew on 8 acres tied into this controller and this system is now stressing me out, so I’m looking into better system. There should also be an active overlay modal of the current progress during a fly run.

title: Superb
text:
I can’t describe what a monumental effort and change the app went through over this winter! It really went from crap to wow. From a below average app to an intelligent informative UI and overall functional. Hat’s off to your dev team. I’m truly impressed. I see that now you give a notification for flex daily why a weather skip didn’t happen; love it! I’m a lawn lover and this app makes me do it so seamlessly. 
I didn’t give 5 stars because I don’t want you to think there isn’t room for improvement :) I think a more concise graph report that shows yearly use like a combo graph where I can show galons of usage as well as weather implication on that; compare year to year or same
Month last year. Reminders to potentially fertilize my lawn as well as aerate it that can be baked within the app. This app has a lot of potential but you’ve done an amazing job! Kudos. 
I do feel bummed out though that I bought the 2nd gen rachio right before the 3rd gen came out

title: Not so intelligent
text:
Good as a manual controller but the “intelligent” part is aweful and unreliable. I’ve had it with this setting. Yesterday we were deluged with rain. The controller sent a notification for today’s schedule watering to be skipped.  I thought this was a great idea. When I woke this morning, I read a notification that today’s watering schedule was complete! But wait, the Rachio unit notified me today’s would be skipped. Looking at more notifications, the unit changed its mind saying, “Due to a change in the weather, today’s watering will occur.” When did I get this notification? At 3:30 in the morning! Thanks I’m always up at 3:30 to check my watering notifications. To make matters worse, we are forecast to get storms and possible heavy rain all weekend. 

Additionally, I can only manually skip the next scheduled watering. Why? If I know what’s coming, how my lawn looks, knows what it needs, why can I not skip two watering?

Th nicest feature about the unit is being able to control it remotely.

title: Go to controller and App
text: I run two of these at two different homes.  The convenience of being able to start and stop from a remote location is game changing.  For those who realize that sprinklers need adjustment on occasions I have no more of adjusting a sprinkler, waking back to a controller to turn it on, then a walk back to check if it is adjusted right, then another walk back to turn it off.  Now I adjust, turn the zone on with my phone, check the sprinkler head and then turn the zone off.... without taking a step. When you finally install one of these you will remember this review and will have wished you would have acted sooner.  No problem with the controller or the app for going on 5 years.  You will not make a mistake with a Rachio controller.

title: Works like it should - The Best
text:
Very easy to install, setup, and connect up. I don't know what the past versions were like, but this one does an awesome job making the system do what it should. I'm very impressed by the weather connection. After installing, we had some rains. It held off from watering to the next day. Very easy to organize the schedule and spontaneous water as needed. The wifi connection couldn't have been easier. 

Scheduling can be simple, create it and forget about it, or highly detailed in which you can micromanage every zone of your yard on a daily basis. Extremely versitile.

The support for this is tremendous. As I look at the reviews, whether good or bad, there seems to be always someone from Rachio giving supportive feedback. They have a comprehensive list of articles that help the user get the most of of their products. The only thing that I have found is that since they removed the "Scheduling" from the bottom menu and placed in the "Calendar" section. They needed to update that in there online info as well.

Someone else had mentioned this in a post as well, if Apple were to design a wireless sprinkler timer, this would be it. Quality packaging and product design.

title: Not that intelligent
text:
Device works fine. Best feature is being able to operate system remotely or when trying to repair sprinklers. So nice to not have to go to controller each time. As far as intelligent not that great. There still needs to be some human intelligence when properly watering a yard if you want your yard to look decent. For example today it skipped watering due to high wind. The closest weather station is probably 10 miles away and they do tend to get higher winds  There is very little wind at my home but it’s going to be 90 plus today. So what’s the plan?  Wait two more days. Not good, not intelligent. 
The app itself is ok but not very intuitive. Typical you can access useless stuff but not the thing you are looking for. 
Also rate this down because does not help save water and water districts should not be subsidizing. Only saves water if you want a dead lawn. 
So great as a controller but not intelligent and not a water saver.

title: Decent app, big oversight!!
text: This app is pretty decent, but the developers have made a big oversight. Absent, is the ability to ”skip” specific dates and times. From an app that is supposed to provide freedom and flexibility to users, this is a huge miss! There are times, like today, where I need to skip both watering sessions for 24 hours. I am not able to do so. The app only lets the user skip the current day’s watering schedule and the first of the following day. There are countless other scenarios whereby a user may want to skip only specific waterings. The developers need to stop trying to get into the user’s head so much that they prevent basic functionality that may be useful to people on an individual basis. This needs to be fixed! The suggestion was made in the Rachio forums several times by many people over the past two years, yet the capability is still missing. The developers need to fix this oversight!!

title: Functional but could be improved in simple but meaningful ways
text:
My number one complaint that totally weights my review is the lack of notification BEFORE the sprinklers come on thereby giving you some time to either move stuff off your lawn like laundry or to skip the water cycle. This functionality is available in $70 smart watering systems. 

Also, unfortunately, the smart watering doesn’t work that well for my location in the SF Bay Area. The system is currently over watering by maybe 2x what it should given the weather and how soaked some things are like the lawn. I’ve tried resetting the schedule with the same results. I’d be nice if it gave me a quick survey or way to give feedback after a watering cycle so that it could use machine learning or some form of logic to adjust dynamically as needed when there are discrepancies between what the app thinks and reality. 

I hope they get there because everything else is quite nice.

title: Ranchio 3
text: I absolutely love having the ability fix a sprinkler head without having to run back and forth from the garage to the zone I’m working on. When doing sprinkler work it is important to bleed the line after the new riser or head is installed. Dirt that is in the pipe will clog up the filter inside the head. I bleed the line by pulling up the pop up part of the head and gently clamping the vice grips on the shaft so it doesn’t go down again. Then I unscrew the top and take out the plastic filter. I then step away and reach for this app to turn on that zone. About 5 seconds is all you need to flush out dirt. Finally, I insert the filter, screw the top back on and remove the vice grips. No more getting wet or running constantly back and forth to the garage!

title: Easy Install and Setup, “one Exception”
text: First I have to say I just only swapped out an existing Controller. The SetUp and Install was way easier than I expected. I only had one problem. The wi-Fi  signal in the yard is marginal in places so I shut off the Wi-Fi and went to cell service. When I did that the program exited from the set up program and I had to manually go in and set up everything. I found no option to get the setup program going again, so possible I missed something? Please add this option. I manually went into each zone and setup those then added a schedule. Hopefully I didn’t miss anything. I will eventually update the review on how well it works.

title: Quick start random messages
text:
I am getting random quick start messages....saying it a quick start has started when I didn’t activate one but nothing is really running. I have run quick start and after it is done I get a message saying quick start was manually stopped when it was not. These random messages don’t match up to any action and it’s really annoying. Even the rain sensor/freeze sensor notification are dumb....it does not tell you that the rain sensor is activated or deactivated like the before. The message was very clear with what was going on....now it does not. I am hoping they fix some of these issues in future updates.

Will bump up to 3 stars. App has a long way to go. Recent updates have helped with my issues. Still some bugs and has a lot of design improvements that are needed.

title: Paid extra for Rachio because of HomeKit that does not work
text:
This is a great sprinkler control and I love it and it worked well for about a year. Then they claim Apple changed something and now for 1.5 years they have simply promised they are working with Apple to resolve the issue. I understand it takes some time, but over a year and half for a deciding feature. All my smart products are HomeKit enabled and it is frustrating that I paid $150 extra for this control compared to the competition for a feature that does not work anymore. I find it ridiculous that they still advertise HomeKit compatibility on their website. 

So I guess the point of this review is do not buy this product thinking you will get HomeKit. You can buy it for being a great controller for a sprinkler if you want, but for the price point they charge you can get something much cheaper with the same features.

title: SO satisfying! (Rachio 3.0) Dallas, TX
text:
This is our 2nd wifi irrigation controller. First we had the Blossom (sadly discontinued because it never worked right after Scotts bought them out!) which was perfect. 

Many functions but the most useful to us was being able to set it for an hour after sunrise so we could check for broken sprinkler heads. It automatically tracked sunrise times & adjusted according.

Rachio unfortunately is missing this particular function, so i have to re-adjust every weekend to following the shorter daylight :(

The Blossom setup was very intuitive where as the Rachio was a little more involved and i had to re-do it twice before it each zone was accurately location labeled. We only have 8 zones - so if you had 12 or 16 it would be extremely tedious!

Thats why it loses a star. Otherwise no complaints. Keeps its wifi connection from day to day. (Blossom kept disconnecting after Scotts took over :( 

Our city allows us to water twice a week (Tues/Fri) so the custom scheduling was also important.

Have been using it for 2 months now. If the sunrise timing function is fixed i’d give it 5 stars… i’ll update my review if it is added! Please !!!

title: App was way better last year
text: I love my Rachio controller but this app has gotten worse over the past year with the new updates.  The layout now is very confusing. If you turn on a zone and go elsewhere in the app it is confusing to figure out how to get back to the zone that is running to turn it off. Everything is buried and not easy to find logically.  Then there is an entire tab dedicated to a product they try to sell you called “Thrive” which I don’t use and never intend to use but there is no way to remove the tab or hide that from the menus.  So to summary with the new changes, everything you need to find quickly is now hidden and cumbersome to use and the features you don’t use like Thrive have a dedicated spot on the front page.  Ridiculous.  Please restore the previous layout and put an option in the settings to not show Thrive.

title: Sprinkler Automation Perfection
text: Our Rachio 2 Sprinkler Controller is awesome!  We’ve had it for 3+ years and I can’t believe we ever had one of those old school control boxes.   I love using the Rachio app.  It makes it so easy to keep the yard looking good while conserving water.  The ability to name and add a picture of each zone allows my wife or landscaper to utilize the app and know exactly how the system is setup.  Another great feature is that Rachio sends out seasonal adjustments for each zone which insures that you don’t over or under water your grass and gardens through out the year.  Don’t wait another minute reading about other controllers, this is the best sprinkler controller in the market!!!

title: Absolutely Love It!!!
text: What a time saver! I love everything about this device and app. It works flawlessly and keeps my garden in ship shape. I have only two suggestions; I would like to be able to time the water flow in seconds. I have a vegetable garden and when I first seed it I need the water to just mist it for around 15 seconds hourly. 1 minute is too much. My other suggestion is that I’d love to be able to arrange the calendar list to my liking. As it is it keeps the list in the order that they’re programmed. To be able to move them around would make keeping track of the schedule much easier. Anyway, my trees and flowers thank you for doing such a great job. This device is one of the best purchases I’ve ever made!

title: Very Satisfied customer
text: I purchased this product to improve my water efficiency and to improve my control. 100% works. It was very easy to replace my old clock. Also, I received a rebate from my local water company that basically paid for this controller. It automatically takes care of rain days. I can very easily set up micro watering for when I do overseeing or fertilizer. All while I’m sitting on my couch tapping my phone. If you ever need to check your sprinkler coverage, there is no walking back-and-forth to the clock to turn it on and turn it off.  Control from anywhere and everywhere. Great product. Get it, you won’t be sorry. Look into the rebate.

title: Fix your app
text: I was excited to control my new sprinkler system with my phone, but imagine how disappointed I was when I couldn’t even “add a controller” and set up my system. I can’t enter my location without the app crashing, which is the first step in setting the whole thing up. Until the app is fixed I have a $200+ piece of plastic on my wall that is nothing more than a wall ornament. How can an app based product fail so badly with the app?! Incredibly frustrating. Especially since all the “reviews” are very favorable. I hope this is just a glitch that will be fixed soon. Until then, this will remain a 1 star review.

title: It used to be a nice app....
text: When I originally got the Rachio controller and the App it was fantastic. Several month ago Rachio decided to update the entire app to a new version. Apparently because the “community” has ask for it. After that, I ran zone 1 and 2 and 3 ran as well. Rachio support staff told me because my valves are maybe dirty. So, I cleaned them and of course it didn’t fix it. Now, I know that the firmware on my controller with the new app caused the issue. Not only did I waste my time but it just proofs how rubbish the app update was. If it ain’t broken, don’t fix it. So, I was told by the Rachio tech support to update force my firmware because I have the old version and it was reported to have my issues. However, that update didn’t work and online it says the firmware update is done automatically. That is NOT the case. Now I am waiting for another email or call from Rachio to fix the issue.

title: Just in time watering!
text: Rachio’s Flex Daily schedules are amazing! Using zone details and local weather data, Rachio monitors the water level in each zone of my lawn to automate my watering. Using a gas tank analogy, it knows if the zone’s water level is empty or full and refills it exactly at a half tank automagically on a zone by zone basis. Some zone water more frequently than others to meet the needs of the plants. There’s not uncommon for the system to skip watering for a week or two at a time, allowing my lawn to use every drop Mother Nature sends my way. The app also gives me control of my sprinklers at my fingertips when I need to fix a head or just want to spray the dog in the back yard! Great product. Highly recommend!

title: Well put together app makes the Rachio even better.
text: I bought a Rachio because my dad‘s just bought a new house which had a Rachio installed as well.I didn’t do much research about this sprinkler controller, but I can say this app is excellently laid out. This app makes the entire unit more fun to use and extremely reliable. I’ve already received one notification that my zones have been automatically adjusted for the amount of time they watered due to the season and I’ve already received a notification that the zones will not water because rain was in the forecast, which it rained hard that day. Love this app, highly recommend the Rachio 3.

title: Transformational product!
text:
Truly one of the best products ever invented! The simplicity of controlling your entire irrigation system from your phone is priceless. I have not used the smart weather feature and was recommended not to given we live in CO (where the weather is unpredictable with regards to rain).  

The only negative (as the reviews say) is the poor customer service. Takes over 2 hours to get through to a rep (I called for a question before I purchased the unit).  However, the product is so easy to install and operate that 99% of you will never need to speak to their service desk. For those that need to, good luck...

title: Run from the comfort of your home
text:
No more standing in the heat of the garage.  Just manually run, when I think necessary, station by station. It tracks performance. Yes I’ve had it since June didn’t really use it for the first few months, read up on it and then started using it. I do the manual ‘pulls’ on it rather than automatic. It’s just nice to be able to touch up a station while you’re drinking your morning coffee.

It would seem a useful bit of information to be able to take over to your MUD and show them how much of your water is not going down the sewer and get it and adjustment on your bill.

title: Worst onboarding
text:
The onboarding experience was one of the worst I have ever had. Lucky I am tech savvy and was able to get threw it:
The app wrongly found my location. After I gave it my address, the app put me in some random location on the map. Then the app allows you to move the pin with no information to where you are on the map (e.g., highways, town names, etc.).
I tried the other way to add my address and found no states in the dropdown. Turns out you need to select you country first, which they don’t tell you. Very frustrating.
CRASHED when setting up first zone…after finally getting threw the basic stuff. When opening the app up again, the setup process was over and I couldn’t find how to start that again. So, I deleted my controller to try and start again.
After deleting my controller, they didn’t mention anywhere that I needed to also reset the controller by holding down the button to reset it. Ugh.
When I got the first zone, again…, the app crashed at a different place and messed up my setup. So, I resolved to figure out the app with no guidance.
I was pretty close to giving up and returning the device.

So far after figuring out all these problems, the app seems to be working okay…Time will tell…🤞🏻.

title: Rachio sprinkler controller
text: Have been using the Rachio 3 Smart Sprinkler controller for a month.  Installed this as a replacement for a Hunter controller on a Hunter sprinkler system.  Was able to install and set up the Rachio controller with no problems.  Using the app it is much easier to test and adjust sprinkler zones.  Am using the smart sprinkler control schedules.  These adapt for soil moisture, climate and season.  Have clay soil, when the controller runs a zone, the sprinklers run for approximately 6 minutes then soak for approximately 30 minutes, the controller will continue to do this until scheduled run is complete.  Takes longer to complete a cycle.  Am pleased with the results.

title: Long time customer
text:
I bought my Rachio four or five years ago and still think it’s the bomb. The automation is great, but so is having the app-based control when I have to adjust the sprinklers. Sure beats running back and forth from the garage turning rainbird on and off!

The app has had its ups and downs and is at a high point now. I find it best to manually program the schedule, rather than use its intelligent schedules. I don’t think they understand high altitude desert issues, which is reasonable. Be careful if you live in an unusual climate. But I haven’t drunk from that intelligent automation well since year one. Maybe it’s better.

title: Better than expected.
text: Got this as a present almost a year ago and just installed it with new landscaping. Super easy install. Great to be able to give new plants extra water as needed. Also don’t have to run out in the morning when it’s raining to turn off the irrigation as this automatically cuts watering cycles when it knows rain (or high wind days) are occurring from location info and internet connection. Also helps to be able to walk the yard and start each zone from the phone to see if the sprinklers are working. Found a bunch that needed different spray pattern heads. So far it’s great.

title: Great Irrigation Controller
text:
We switched from a 20 year old Hunter controller that was watering every day.
The Rachio 3 was very simple to install. We we up and running in 30 minutes.
It tracks the weather and adjusts the watering schedule accordingly. We have saved a lot of water since we have added the Rachio 3, around a 30% reduction in our water bill. The Rachio 3 will pay for itself in 2 years. 
When blowing out the system for the winter, remote access is huge and makes accessing zones without having to run back and forth to the basement so much easier. 
I highly recommend this product.

title: Sprinklers Re-Engineered
text: The Rachio team definitely has something going for them here. From getting my unit to sprinklers up and running…and even beyond,the app was developed smartly by stepping everyone through the same setup process. I currently use only 4/8 stations on my unit, but station setup, run time, even picking the slope and type of soil and sun received during the day are all super easy options to set when station setting. When it starts raining at my house I also get a push notification telling me the weather skip function has been enabled, and later that night I get a follow up email with the same info. Keep it up Rachio!

title: Complicated and unintuitive.
text: Many usability issues.  Several years ago I asked them to better show everything that’s happening on the calendar and they didn’t take my advice.  They don’t listen to their customers. Hard to determine when zones will run again on the flex daily schedule. The calendar view could easily display each schedule with unique color but instead shows a small number that doesn’t indicate what the additional schedules are for that day. Like to be able to filter the calendar view by schedule.  I do not care about monthly usage but that’s all it shows.  Need to know weekly usage since everything is watered weekly. Doesn’t seem like the flex schedule waters my roses enough (shrubs).  Sadly I end up using fixed schedule without any intelligence because it doesn’t work reliably otherwise.

title: Grate product and customer support
text:
I have a big yard with many plants and eight watering channels. Rachio controller made my life much easier. Application is very easy to use and covering all possible watering needs like wether, daytime and seasonal adjustments. 
The most important for me is that I can start and stop watering from my phone staying at place where I working with my sprinklers. 

My unit worked perfect one and a half years and then I got problem with WiFi connection. 

Usually I don’t like call to customer service. First you are doing all troubleshooting routine by yourself then all the same  with operator on the phone and after that you are connected to the person who really can help you and all starts over.

But this is not story about Rachio. At the end of troubleshooting procedure i got message that there is opened ticket for my case and i will get email with instructions. WOW I don’t need to call to customer service and ask for help. Soon i got new unit for replacement.

title: Threw away $260 unit.
text: My gardener sets up this unit he picked out. He set up as a service person which should allow the owner to get in. But I could not get in. So he closes his down and I still could not get in. I did text Support about it but didn’t see any email or anything coming back to me. I did get endless advertising and spam from them trying to sell me stuff many times a week. It’s cool that it can be controlled by the phone but the only other way to control it is a button on the unit where you hit it three times and hope that you were on the third? Fourth? System. No display. Then another person comes to work in the yard and has no means to turn on water. It’s just a ridiculous system. I replaced it with another brand that has simple display screen on the unit and a fantastic application.

title: Why Isn’t Everyone Using Rachio?
text:
The most advanced residential watering management system available. This is the 2nd system I’ve owned having sold a previous home. Installation by far easier than PID controllers and a No Contest for daily operation. I’m amazed how many sprinkler systems installer folks aren’t aware of this awesome system.
I’m in bed at night and message come thru “ Rain Skip enacted” now I’m not having to shut off my system when a rain deluge heads my way.
Crazy easy to operate using my IPhone 
If you don’t have this system and you’ve got a lawn to water, your doing it the hard way.

title: Great device and app.
text: This app is awesome. For some reason it thought I had a master pump when it setup automatically but I turned it off in the app.  The buttons on the device are finicky.  More manual control from the Rachio itself would be great but overall it does what it is supposed to do. The app more than compensates for the manual controls.  I recommend getting used to the advanced features to hone in on what your lawn and yard need.  My rachio is already saving a ton of water and $$$$.  One item I would like to see added software wise is the ability to add more areas while the QuickStart is running instead of stopping it and creating a new custom QuickStart.

title: Interface gets every year worse.
text:
First year was great, even though the flowmeter is useless (reports 2/3 too little pressure), but the calculation when the yard needed water was stable and reliable (after a little tweaking).

Spring 2019 brought negative surprises: yard watering schedule calculations all over the place, not reliable at all and an app which interface had got worse over the winter months.

Come 2020, and somehow the company managed to make the experience even worse: pushing their new product in which I’m not interested in, having its icon on the menubar, but what I constantly need (shedules) I have to go hunt down under the ’more’ settings. Super annoying dashboard with a lot of useless information in your face (how to water your yard and stuff like that which you might, might read 1x - so put it under ‘more’ stuff!). The system now reacts really slow, what worked well before is now barely usable, communication between the phone app and the controller is horribly delayed and sluggish at the best moments.

What has been an investment which was exciting and helpful in 2018 has become a nightmare to use and currently I regret very much having gone down the Rachio route.

title: App is virtually impossible to read on an iPad
text:
The corporate policy is apparently to pay app designers to intentionally make the app virtually impossible to read on an iPad. They seem to forget that faint light color text on a white background will make the app and thus set up and control of their system impossible.

Black on white text would be readable. Very light blue or green on white is not very readable, even with magnifiers and various ambient lighting conditions. Sadly, I am a long term user of this product and very disappointed in that each time I try to set schedules, read help files or make changes in setup I cannot read the app on an iPad or iPhone. 

Please fire the app designer unless he can be made to understand that black on white text is easy to read. Faint, light colors on white is not readable for most users.

title: Works but ...
text: The system does what it is supposed to do as long as it is set up correctly.  I love the “quick run” feature when areas need a little bit more.   I just wish it was designed for the average consumer.  If you need to adjust something, there are so many terms that don’t mean anything to someone who just wants to make it water more or less often.  Also, the nearest weather station that the software uses to decide when next to water is in a completely different micro climate from us so the watering schedule often isn’t appropriate.  If I could have kept our previous system (which went out of business) I would have.

title: Ruined a perfectly good app
text: His new version has destroyed a nice app.  I just woke up and wanted to see if it ran this morning.  The old app I would have seen that on the home screen.  I was tapping all over looking for it.  Finally found it but got sidetracked by the “minimalist” interface.  Is so stripped down it’s practically useless.  And I no longer get alerts telling me the schedule didn’t run.  Minor issues that pretty much underscore the care that wasn’t taken: in the calendar the days of the week headers aren’t lined up with the dates, and they’re off by enough it’s not obvious where they belong.  In the history there is a note that reads “to learn more about saturation skip tap the ? Above — there is no ? Above or below.  Do the designers even use a sprinkler system?

title: Most recent update not an improvement
text: Makes more sense to keep the zones tab labeled as zones instead of yard. The moisture % is no longer displayed for each zone under the yard tab. It just says “soil moisture...” and have to click on the actual zone to see the moisture. The history section should be in the calendar view and the schedule section should kept its own section. Don’t understand why the most recent changes were made. The layout was fine the way it was before. Also the sprinklers aren’t running on the daily flex schedule when they’re supposed to after dropping below 50% moisture. Have had to manually run zones that were dropping into the single digits before they were scheduled to run on the flex daily schedule.

title: Great app
text:
User friendly, easy to setup and use. The map plot and zones pictures make it very descriptive and the  quick run option is very helpful. 

The rain gauge sensor and pump output make it a complete system for any application. But the most important is the WiFi capability. This is a feature I have never seen so far in an advanced system like this. 

The only drawback is that the controller needs the included adapter for power, which means convenience for any DYI warrior, but it also creates and unsightly wire hanging down the wall and the bulky transformer plugged into an outlet. Which makes the slick controller look like it was cheaply installed. I would like to see a hardwired option. This would be perfect for those who can run the power in wall from an external transformer, or a built in plug on the back of the controller, this option would conceal the outlet it is plugged in as well. 

All in all a great system.

title: Great so far
text: I am very happy with the sprinkler timer. I had a bit of trouble connecting it to the Internet when setting up. But once connected, it works great. Had a rainy April and May. It has saved me a ton of water already. It is easy to operate from your phone anywhere if you want to do a quick run on any or all zones. It gives me notifications when watering has started, completed and when it suspends operation due to the forecast. I highly recommend. I am excited to try the fertilizer and soil testing service.

title: So-so
text:
If you have an iPhone 11 running 13.4.1 or later, set up will not work. When trying to add the sprinkler controller to your wifi network you will get “an expected error occurred” message. 

You will have to use a different device.  I reset the wifi on the unit and then removed the controller on the app.  Then installed the app on another device (iPAD) and went through set up again and then it worked.

Once it is set up and connected to wifi then the app also worked on the iPhone 11 (seems the problem is with the wifi setup).

Setting up all the zones was tedious as the app got stuck on updating (each zone) multiple times, requiring having to restart the app and then start the setup of that zone again.  Out of 8 zones this happened 4x.

App is attractive and well laid out.  Programming the watering went fine.  Instructions for installing the unit were well done.

title: Rachio Sprinkler Controller/App
text: The system is extremely easy to setup. Very quick with no software glitches. Super easy to use on phone. Quick run feature is great when testing new additions or making repairs. Have recommended to many of my tech savvy and tech challenged friends,lol. No issues with connecting and auto rain off features are also very nice and makes sense. The smart features are nice but make sure it works for your region.  Same price as other systems with less features and more issues.

title: Good basic functionality, awful UI
text: While the app and the controller ‘get the job done’, the UI leaves so much room for improvement. For instance, you can’t review your schedule on a calendar. And you can’t view or update your programs in a table format. So your left having to write everything down on paper, and then adjust from there. Also, many updates to basic settings -such as changing the schedule program frequency from specific days to every day or every other day - require a complete redo of the schedule program. Either I have a high standard, or am significantly missing something, but I’m shocked at how high of a rating this app gets by most people!

title: Great irrigation system!
text:
Easy to setup, easy to set schedules or just run manually from anywhere where there is internet access.  The intelligent watering works great and saves water.  The system is watching the weather and will skip a watering schedule when this feature is on.  

As a side note, I do my own winterization so it’s real easy to just use your phone to turn on a zone and let the air compress push out the water without running back and forth to a control panel to open and close valves.

title: Good system
text: Good system overall. Allows you to set up different zones and control the time fir each zone. Easy to quickly pull up a zone and activate it for extra watering. I’d like to see them add a feature so that you could program start times seperately for weekends vs weekdays. We like sleeping with our windows open and when we can sleep in the noise of the sprinklers will wake us up. Sure you could set all days to be later, but it’s just software, why not give us a bit more control?

title: Complicated for nothing
text: You updated the Rachio app making it look pretty to look at but making the actual use of the App harder! It’s more difficult to do simple things, and even more click waste just to navigate. The old view you can see the exact time and details of each watering schedule which is good to know specially during times of seasonal changes but not it doesn’t even show that anymore! If I can go back to the old version will do so immediately.

title: Good but not great.
text:
Works well love the pics on the interface but falls short for larger systems and programming.   I have 19 zones wanted a controller, there answer was buy 2, so I did.  Trouble is they are handled in the software as 2 controllers.  When I look for a zone I have to first pic a controller and I do t know what controller the zone is under.  Also never figured out scheduling I wanted to make different programs for different times of year and even a blow out program that turns on one zone after another and pauses 15 min between zones so my compressor can catch up.  

Overall love the controllers though just wish programming was better.

title: Easy to use, Intelligence Weather, Panel Access
text: Phone app very easy to use and convenient. The Intelligence Weather features help save water. Just changed to new router and had to reconnect the controller, which was easy once I figured out how to open the face panel. There is a lip in the bottom of the controller, but very had to open (I thought I would break it). Need instructions to say “take cover off”, which is missing on the app instructions. Other than that, I would highly recommend.

title: Conflicting info
text:
The app is nice overall, but I don’t trust what it’s telling me. For example, a zone shows Soil Moisture 64% in the zones list, but 63% on the zone info page. Sure it’s only one percent, but why? The soil moisture chart detail shows a rise in moisture on Sep 4 from irrigation of 0.45 on that day, but there’s no watering in the schedule until Sep 5; the chart shows no increase on that day. Finally, the chart shows 0.11 inches precipitation from my personal weather station today, but my station is only reporting 0.08 inches of rain.

These details matter as errors like this do not instill confidence that the rest of the app is doing what it claims to be doing.

title: Water savings and much more
text: I bought the 1st Gen of Rachio first thing when we bought our house, and it’s been an investment that I am very happy with. I’ve recommended it to many of my family and friends! After a few years, I upgraded to Rachio Gen 3, and I’m even more impressed. Looks better, easier to setup, and more options. Besides the fact that you never have to worry about running the sprinkler system, this is great for saving water and keep your grass in good health. Highly recommend!

title: Way under priced
text: I work in the automation industry and chose this product due to its ability to integrate with a Crestron control system. The product is amazing and the app is so intuitive. It’s really done well and based on the weather forecast it will not water your lawn. Not only is your lawn not over saturated but it saves 1230 gallons of water at my house each time it skips a cycle. Extra watering is so simple too! It’s really a great product and I have no clue why this product isn’t far more money.

title: Makes life easier
text: In the past I have the old fashion I will call it because I have to Raccio it is nothing but old. This system was introduced to me from a friend, couldn’t be more pleased nothing like being miles away and being able to turn on the water or turn it off if need be. We have a pool surrounded by flowers and I mean surrounded we have a drip irrigation system hooked into it before we would have to go water it with the garden hose! Like my title says makes life easier perfect.

title: Added intelligence
text:
I appreciate the added intelligent and flexible scheduling of this module. It works in ways that other lawn sprinkler controllers don’t do. It sprays your lawn in intervals which allows water to soak your lawn, then return to spray your lawn again to give it the needed amount of water.  

One other feature is it uses the weather forecast to schedule the watering. It has many weather stations for you select from Wunderground. This eliminates the need for a rain sensor. 

It is also very simple to install.

title: They broke it this year and it’s killing my lawn
text:
Everything worked great for 3 years and the rain skip feature was much more reliable than a rain sensor. This year they added all sorts of “smart” features and automatically started saving water so aggressively everything is dieing and brown. The rain skip feature has now skipped 5 days and there hasn’t been any rain (the forecast was 10% yesterday and 40% today).

They’ve made it very difficult to just configure it as a timer to water when I want it to for as long as I want it to and the rain skip has stopped working.

This was 5 stars until this year, I guess this is the danger of trusting a cloud service with this sort of thing. It’s their lawn now and not mine.

title: The best, most convenient app for my home landscaping
text: This is incredibly convenient and easy to use. It’s intuitive. Programming is very simple. Ever need to repair a bad sprinkler head? Then you’ll find it amazing how you can turn the water on and off from the convenience of your phone being right at that sprinkler. Plus, the option to let the smart system override your settings based on the weather in my neighborhood is not only intelligent but good for the environment and good for my water bill.

title: Best app on my phone and still is
text:
April 21 update:  The recent app enhancements are phenomenal. It’s clear MUCH thought goes into the design and user experience. Everything is so logical. Thank you Rachio!!!

I have been using the Rachio sprinkler system for three years it works perfectly. 

The controller always connects to my home network when I access it through the app. Being able to control my sprinkler system anywhere I am helps tremendously. 

When we travel I don’t even think to leave the schedule on or off. I keep up with the weather and turn it off or on when needed. 

This system has saved countless gallons of water and money by shutting it off when an unexpected rain shower appears and I can easily turn it off. 

Lastly the app design is perfect. Everything is where it should be. Keep up the great work!!

title: Water times don’t make sense
text: I set up the schedule for the flex saving, which is suppose to use the least amount of water, and it’s saying it’s going to water each my 8 zones for crazy long periods of time, like over an hour for each zone for a total of 11 hours and 59 minutes on my watering days. And my yard is super shady, which I indicated when I was setting up my zones which I would think would reduce the amount of water my yard needs. Before I got this I was watering each zone for like 10 minutes on my watering days which I thought was probably more than it needed, maybe I should of been watering non stop for 12 hours straight at night lol.

title: Great ease of use, mediocre ease of use
text:
I’ve used the old-fashioned Rainbird-type controllers for years.  These are super-hard to use.  So I was thrilled to buy a controller that used the iPhone. By that standard, the Rachio app is great.  

As iPhone apps go, it has always frustrated me. Here’s an example.  The other day I noticed that one of my sprinkler risers had broken and water was shooting in the air.  For the life of me I couldn’t figure out how to stop it.  

I don’t have to use the app very often.  When I do use it I find myself having to think hard about how to do what I want to do.  To me the app is not intuitive.  The recent changes didn’t help as far as I’m concerned.

title: App great customer service lacking
text: I find the app very intuitive and easy to use. Setting up schedules and using the suggested features like smart cycle helps to save water. Customer service is seemingly non-existent like many companies these days. They want you to service through previous articles and there really is no one to contact if your issue is not in the articles. Install was easy as was setup because of the well designed app. Just hope you don’t run into any issues as you might be on your own.

title: I love it ....but
text:
I really like this app and watering system. It could however be a little more user-friendly, by that I mean prompts to get you to the right spot quickly. For instance; do you want to delay watering today? Do you want to set a new time for specific? Do you want to set a different direction for watering a zone?How long am I watering this on now?

I think You get the jest it’s just difficult to navigate for someone who does not use this app on a daily basis.

title: Wind Skip Inaccuracies
text:
I find that for my area, the declaration of a wind skip based on expected winds greater than 20 mph are rarely accurate. I’d say maybe only 5-10 % of the times it is declared and put into effect are there any such winds.
Also, on almost all occasions when wind skips are declared, there almost never seems a time that any wind occurs sooner than 6 to 10 hours after a scheduled watering. 
In addition, why aren’t adjustments made for adding back a watering after a Wind Skip.  
Overall I do love the Rachio system on the whole- it’s amazing.

title: iOS issues/ can’t connect
text:
I’ve had my Rachio 3 for about a year now and it was a headache to get connected the first time. I had to use 3 different phones before it was setup and connected due to Rachios poor app and updates. They don’t communicate with anything over iPhone X. 

I recently had changed my internet provider over and now it’s impossible to connect to the WiFi. I’ve tried close to a hundred times and for the past week I’ve only gotten “an expected error occurred. Try again.” That’s it, for nearly a hundred time that’s all I’ve gotten. 

I will tell you that when it works, it’s fantastic, but unfortunately, Rachio really makes you put in the work to get it, if you even can.

title: Get rid of Thrive for the people that don’t use it
text: I had my Rachio app on the old version where the user interface made the most sense. Now most complaints are on the new version and for that reason, I stayed with the old version. But now I was forced to update to this horrible home page. It doesn’t make any sense.. all these lawn care information on the main page should be tucked inside the help menu. And your Thrive product doesn’t deserve its own tab. We don’t use it, we don’t want it! Your app screenshots are misleading because it doesn’t show Thrive.. We just simply want to water our lawn with simplicity and efficiently.. And your old interface did just that. The reviews aren’t lying.

title: Saves time , money and headaches
text:
I have used the Rachio controller for over 2 years now. I love the flex schedule which takes current weather conditions into account to run or not run my irrigation system. I have 9 zones. The most difficult thing was to setup each zone properly depending on type of plant (grass, tree, shrub, flowers) , soil type (compacted clay loam), slope of zone. 

Rachio has settings for Clay Loam soil but not compacted soil types which is typical of new construction which is what I have. 

If it had something for new yards I would rate it a 5.

title: Sprinkler system remote operation
text: It has been great to have a sprinkler system with remote operation from our phones and this system is user friendly and intuitive. Adding remote operation to our new sprinkler system added relatively little additional cost and was well worth the additional investment. If you are thinking about investing in a new sprinkler system or upgrading an existing system, you will not be disappointed.

title: No support for landscape based on drop emitters
text: For most of the people in the south western United States that do not have lawns or large areas of grass Rachio has seemed to forget about us. I have no grass in my yard and just plants based off drip emitter heads in desert landscapes and it was extremely difficult to make a water schedule based on that without having to use a lot of back doors and tricks based off user input on the forums. In my opinion this is pretty poor for such a mature product. Not sure I would recommend this product to anyone I know here in Arizona based off of this. I wish I would’ve chosen a different irrigation controller.

title: Rachio Review
text: This is the best invention ever, especially during a drought.   It is soooo easy to program and add a cycle or eliminate or shorten a cycle depending on the weather and temperature.   I used to forget sprinklers were on and would over water way too often.   Now it is easily programmed and easily changed depending on circumstances.   I had an automatic system before but programming was all manual which did not make it easy.   Now it is a breeze!!! Thanks so much!

title: Less of a blessing than we had hoped.
text:
Installation is easy. But you need to do that only once. The system works fine, but the app is useless. After a year of use, my gripes:
1. Whenever you need the app, it first needs to update. Ugh. 
2. The app is slow in starting up. Ugh even more. 
3.  We mainly need the app to pause or stop the watering, eg during picnic or play. Well, considering 1 and 2 above, if you don’t want to get the food ruined and the blankets or seats wet, it’s faster to run to the controller and take action from there, than using the app. 
4. When you temporarily do not water a section, it’s hard to find it to start watering g again 

We still have sections running on an old non-app conventional Hunter controller. Much easier in cases of emergency. But, indeed, we need to do the seasonal and other adjustments manually there. On the other hand, on is on and off is off and nobody gets wet.

title: Easy to use
text: By the looks of it, compared to the standard controllers I’ve seen, I was skeptical. It just looks very basic. But after having it a few weeks, “basic” is the point. It was super easy to install— took me maybe an hour to go from box to a running system. The app is super easy to use as well, and the intelligence settings make it even better. I highly recommend it to anyone.

title: Junk. Dumbest system I’ve ever used.
text:
I set everything up in the system correctly and it says it should water for… a few minutes… every 8 days… in summer… in Phoenix. You don’t need to be a rocket scientist to know this schedule would be the same as just spraying weed and grass killer all over the lawn. Same outcome. Everything dead. 

Their support is worthless. When I contact them they just copy paste a canned response that has no relation to my issue. Not sure they even read the messages that come in.

If I hadn’t gotten a rebate for it I would return it immediately. It’s so bad I’m considering paying for a different system out of pocket just so I can throw this one away.

title: Works Great
text: Had no issues with the app. Just have to be patient when setting up your zones. The processing screen may run for 30 seconds to 1 minute but it doesn’t crash. All in, it took 20 minutes to set up 7 zones in the app. The only issue I have is that I can’t seem to just schedule a single watering, for example, if I want to just schedule a watering a couple of days from now, it won’t allow me to unless I set up a scheduling frequency. Other than that, happy so far.

title: Worthless
text: I’m trying to set up my system that was already installed in a home I purchased. I was going through the steps to sync it to my phone and got to a point where the app said “this system is already in use, contact support.” Well, there’s no real support to contact. I tried the chat bot, worthless. Then you have to send an email that could take 3 days to receive a reply to. What a waste of time. Worthless.

title: Rachio 3 for the win
text: Installation is outlined to easy install.  Even for those not that handy.  Set up to full capacity does take some time but I love the availability to take a photo of watering area.  Makes it easy for anyone wanting to do a quick watering.  This feature is great especially for new grass or landscaping.  30 day out and extremely happy.  Will be interested in checking if my water bill changes compared to old unit.

title: App crashes 50% of the time
text: Actual sprinkler controller hardware is great. The app features and functionality has everything I want. Interface is easy to use. But the app crashes almost every other time I use it on my iPhone X. Especially when I click on my Yard button it just crashes. It crashed when I was in the middle of my initial set up of my zones. Luckily the app is intuitive enough that I didn’t need the guided wizard to complete setup. App also randomly crashes when I’m uploading pictures of my zones. Would’ve been a 5 star review except all the crashes render this app only semi useful and very frustrating to use.

title: Saving money
text:
I have installed a Rachio controller on my main residence and two rental properties. In all three cases, my water bill have dropped significantly. 

The weather intelligence has cancelled many scheduled events and all three lawns look great. I highly recommend this controller over any controller that is dependent on an old type rain sensor mounted to the side of the cost. 

My first controller paid for itself in just under a year based on the water savings.

title: Easy to set and just Go!
text:
I love the aspect that our city is able to monitor our use with us, so if water is needed elsewhere it’s just automated.   And I love the whole connection with weather satellites to really give you a healthy lawn without watering on rainy days.

And the connection to your smartphone through the app is great, on 90+ degree days to be able to start for just a few minutes to cool the yard down after the sun sets.

title: Love it
text: This is a great watering system with an easy to use App. This is our 2nd house using this system. I’m in the process of landscaping my backyard and this App makes it so much easier to water just the areas I need when adding new plants and flowers. We also have it set to the auto water and it detects rain fall so it won’t run then, unlike some other systems. Very easy to use and have recommended it to my friends. 😃

title: Very slick system
text: Rachio is the best predictive irrigation system available on the market. Most irrigation system are based upon what has happened ie it just rained. Rachio exams the approaching weather to determine if there’s going to be a storm and thus it can skip watering that day.  I’ve used it for four years, not always perfect but easy to make local adjustments if a zone is looking a bit parched. Mostly it’s transparent, set it up and forget it.

title: You are going to love it
text: This system is the best!  It is weather dependent and saves me a ton of money.  It’s paid for itself in water bill savings in 3 months.  You can control the system on your phone and makes it great for turning on and off the water if you have sprinklers to adjust without having to go back to the main panel each time.  That in itself is worth it.  Super easy to install!!

title: So convenient
text: I really enjoy my rachio app. I live in Arizona and the summers are especially hot. It’s so convenient to go into the app and set a quick run on a zone in need of water. The only thing is I cannot figure out how to have the water run before it gets to 0% moisture. I think that stresses the plants too much. But it’s definitely better than having to go outside and turn in manual water. I think it really helps to conserve water

title: Great System
text: This is great device. It waters based on weather reports and is completely integrated with WiFi. I never have to go to the box. I had a small leak in my system so I had to turn on system at shut off valve before I could run. My sprinkler guy set up system so valve opens when watering starts and shuts off once over. This saved me trying to find a small leak that would have cost a fortune.

title: Automagic- Rachio makes irrigation work
text: Have been a Rachio customer for 4 years and continue to be amazed and impressed with their pace of innovation. While I’ve been an advocate for the Rachio irrigation controller, I’ve provided consumer feedback and have consistently been pleased and surprised by the quick responses, help and improvements. The current controller and mobile and web apps are the best automation apps I have. Highly recommend to anyone looking to automate and simplify their annual landscape irrigation.

title: Has turned my garden into a desert
text: I have tried to use its automated setting.  It doesn’t water for weeks at a time, even though we have had NO rain.  I play with the settings; plant type, soil type, sun percent, etc.  it’s killing everything.  I will have to use it manually.  And...I have asked customer service repeatedly for assistance.  There is no phone number and they keep sending me the same email telling me how the auto irrigation function works even though I keep telling them it is not working if it’s watering once a month and we have had no rain...so I must conclude unfortunately that the customer service is useless.

title: Horrible experience
text: Im not sure if this id a good product because i couldn't set it up; the app kept crashing when I tried to install the device. I called the company and they said i could use their website on any web browser as a workaround. Mobile browser interface is just awful. Desktop browser isn't much better, and then when i click on “add device” it tells me to please download the app to add a device. I cant use the app because it keeps crashing. Called customer service back and they had no idea what they were talking about and then the call disconnected halfway through. I gave up. Returning it.

title: App won’t open!
text: For the first couple of weeks the app worked great. It takes a little trial and error to work out the skips/don’t skip tricks and yes, there is inconsistent information on different pages which is not helpful, but the run history was usually correct at least. But now my app won’t even open. I’ve tried force-closing it several times and even turned my phone off/on, but I keep getting an error that “we’re having trouble get your account information.” I’ll hit the “retry” button over and over to no avail. I can’t even use the controller if the app won’t open! What the hell?! What am I supposed to do now??

title: Irrigation timer to the next level
text: I have been using it for 2.5 months now with a flex schedule. Took a little time to get setup the first time but my grass has never been better and it adjusted based on the season exactly what I had to do manually before. It connected to my personal weather station flawlessly and has skipped when it needed to based on rainfall. Would recommend this to anyone. Looking forward to the best lawn next year.

title: Nice Controller
text:
I like the controller. Very easy to install and setup in the app. The app does a nice job of managing water usage using local weather stations and keeping me informed using notifications. 
The app is not intuitive for me. I spend too much time hunting for the features I’m looking for. If there’s an override function for weather related changes made by the controller (and there should be) I can’t find it. 
HomeKit support should be included. But no iPad  support??!  That’s a bummer for me.

title: Mixed bag
text: In my last home the Rachio system was a lifesaver during our hit dry summers. The automation and seasonal shifts were flawless. However in the new home-only five miles away-the new Rachio systems have not been consistent and I’ve list trees. A reset or update changed my selected 20 minutes a day in high sumner to three minutes once a week. Thus past Saturday Rachio initiated a rain skip and there weren’t even clouds in the forecast. The settings and location are correct. I now use Rachio manually so as to not lose and more landscaping.

title: Superior
text: Uncomplicated setup - my irrigation installer took a pic of each zone when setting the app. I set up watering days according to city’s requirements. We put a sensor in the yard that works with the Rachio system. When it rains, the irrigation system won’t run until it senses the soil is ready - it’s very smart. The app allows me to water one zone if I plant something new, as well as setting the length of time of the run. VERY happy with Rachio & the app!

title: Usability
text: I do wish they would use more homeowners to bata test apps for the public instead of programmers. It makes no sense on many functions how one must search for 15 minutes to make the simplest of changes. This also must use a rain gauge for best results. The local weather stations are inaccurate in a dry southern climate. They may get two inches of rain 9 miles away and we get nothing. Over all, it’s one of the best out there but the end users need more say as to how one gets to simple scheduling functions.

title: a sprinkler system everyone can love
text:
I installed my Rachio over a year ago and find it is the best possible solution for control of a lawncare sprinkler system 
I can set the schedule from anywhere using the application Rachio designed.
I recommend this as an easily installed and set replacement for the obsolete system I had. Once connected to your Wifi you control from your phone.
Love my Rachio!

title: Excellent Program - Rachio
text: Have been using an earlier version of the Rachio controller. It’s never missed a beat and has saved me a whole bunch of time with sprinkling activities in my lawn. I primarily run the controller from my iPhone and this can be done anywhere I can get an iPhone signal, which is virtually most anywhere in the US. Better yet, they have a great and attentive staff. In short, they are “on it”.

title: So cool!!
text:
This rachio system is ultra efficient. The flexibility of setting up as many schedules as you want is over the top. 

And the app has many features I would not have dreamed possible. For example, one late afternoon my wife asked if I could give extra water to the flower pots on the deck. I just pulled my phone out and I’m seconds the drip emitters activated. 

Highly recommend this system and app

title: Watch out for spam
text:
I have two reviews, one for the controller and one for Rachio marketing. 

1. The controller will get a five star. It works very well with many convenient options.  I have nothing bad to say about the equipment. 

2. Up until recently I would have given this product and the company 5 stars. They want to market their fertilizer which I am not interested in and they will send you emails and when you opt out they again spam you with a questionnaire. 

The app is now full with advertisements for their fertilizer with no way to shut it off and not see it. 

You should not have pushed another business upon customers who did not request or invite interest. 

Knowing now what they are doing makes me wish I had purchased other products from other companies that don’t spam you.

title: Finally water sensor, now better graphs needed
text:
A gripe that I have had with this app for a couple of years has been finally been addresses: an easy way to see the status of the rain sensor.  Now, if only we could configure a rain delay or a moisture balance based in that...
Also, I like to graphs but why the detail has to be chopped and then displayed only in portrait?   I struggle with scrolling and losing the row names pane.  It would really nice if you could freeze the panes or allow for a landscape view.

title: Love it but....
text:
My gardener put the rachio system in for us.  He shared the ability to make changes.  However, he quit.  I removed him from sharing.  But I have no instructions or manual to refer to. I’m not sure how to use the system. My new Gardner doesn’t have cell phone to share and doesn’t know how to use system.  

I believe a manual should be available even if have to purchase it. 

Gramma

title: Lots of 1 Star reviews. Seems odd to me. It’s been flawless for me.
text: This App has been great. I have 2 neighbors with this product and they say it’s fantastic. Fortunately for me I had them to trust vs coming here and seeing all the 1 Star reviews. I just finished putting fertilizer down and enjoyed standing in my yard turning sprinklers on. I even uploaded my yard zone photos to the App. Excellent product! I have Rachio 3 system.

title: Not intuitive enough. But needs more customization.
text:
Interface is too complicated. I don’t need to use your app very often and I end up struggling to remember how it works twice a year. 
Put Schedules on the bottom menu. Remove Zones; I setup my zones years ago and I’ve never needed to access that page since. Remove Thrive; I don’t intend to use it. Or allow customizing the menu. 
I wish to start a Schedule now, but there is no way to do that. You can start one tomorrow, but if you didn’t start a schedule yesterday then you’re out of luck for today. Add an option to start a Schedule as a Quick Run.

title: Great potential, but not very smart
text:
I’ve resorted to manually turning standby mode on and off, because the smart weather features don’t work that well. And yes, I have it properly setup and linked to a functioning weather station nearby. The main problem is that Rachio insists on watering even as downpours are approaching. It doesn’t seem to “look forward” in a very intuitive manner. After it rains a lot, it will delay watering, but often not long enough.

I like being able to control remotely, but was hoping for more... especially for the cost.

title: Outstanding product and app
